sentences.sentence: The nation Dropping $240m on a stadium in Hobart is at odds with what the Labor government has forecast about the future.It's not often a prime minister gets heckled for making a major funding announcement, particularly when it's a major funding announcement involving football.But in what feels like a symbol of a contradictory set of messages from the federal government in the lead-up to Tuesday's Budget, Anthony Albanese was filmed striding across derelict land in Hobart last Saturday, pursued by protesters heckling him as he announced $240 million of funding for a new football stadium.The protesters weren't just political fringe dwellers expressing a minority opinion.
The proposal to build a football stadium at Macquarie Point has been widely unpopular for some time.

Apart from a poll showing 67 per cent of Tasmanians were against the stadium, it has been opposed by state Labor, the Greens, federal independents and federal Liberals.As Richard Flanagan wrote in The Age this week, Tasmanians living in the poorest state with the lowest incomes have endured the nation's biggest rental increases in the past five years, have the highest increase in homelessness, the worst public heath system and, with 50 per cent rate of functional illiteracy, a public education problem.Yet the state government has committed $375 million to the stadium project which is now viable thanks to the federal commitment.
Well, it is chucking in just $15 million on the promise that it will not have to pay any more if costs blow out.So why on earth would Albanese get involved?

The fig leaf that seeks to make a virtue of the federal government's involvement is the sudden materialisation of references to broader urban renewal, and notably social and affordable housing on the site about two months ago, when the prime minister was being asked about the project.
"We're considering proposals as part of our budget measures, but I make this point, we're considering it as part of an urban redevelopment and urban policy," he said on February 23.
"That is a prime site for not just a sporting stadium, if that goes ahead, but for residential, for recreational, for commercial activity as well.

A submission (still forthcoming) that would clearly differ from a plan that made no reference to urban renewal or housing.Even now, if you care to look it up, artist impressions show a dirty, big stadium and a vaguely shaded-in area nearby which "could" be the possible site of some housing.How much housing?

The original number mentioned was just 120 homes - though the suggestion this week is that there might be more after the government tweaked its housing fund plan to guarantee a minimum of 1200 homes would be built in Tasmania over the next five years.Given this has all been magicked up in record time, it will be interesting to hear at Senate estimates just how much detailed infrastructure planning was put forward to the federal government before it "apparently" committed to this funding last week.Infrastructure Minister Catherine King told ABCHobart on Tuesday that "the first thing is the Tasmanian government needs to come back to the Commonwealth with a precinct plan that includes the housing development, social and affordable housing" among other things, "as they develop that plan with the RSL, with Hobart City Council and with First Nations communities as they go through that".This would just be a story about what looks like tin-eared politics and decisions on the run with few ramifications in the rest of the country, if it wasn't for the fact there seems to be a bit of that vibe going on more broadly in the past few weeks.For starters, there's the eye watering amounts of money being spent on defence - even before the revelations that there was a $123 billion contingency for cost overruns on the nuclear submarine program, let alone the subsequent big investment decisions which keep coming for other forms of kit.Yet on the other side of the fence, the government keeps warning us about how tough things are in the budget: how it had to find another $5 billion for "unfunded" government programs and activities (that is, programs that the previous government only funded until this year); and detailed releases about huge debt interest bills linked to the former government.And there is the one constant message that although this coming year might look okay, the years beyond will look worse, which constrains the government from doing all that people ask of it to improve the condition of the more than 3 million people living below the poverty line.The optics of the PM attending the multimillion-dollar wedding of a shock jock in the company of underworld figures, before jetting off to mix with royalty at the coronation might have further confused voters who felt that they had a handle on their working-class prime minister.If all these messages weren't making things complicated enough, an obscene amount of revenue has emerged in recent days from underforecast profits that suggests the budget's heading for a significant surplus - the first in 15 years.As economist Chris Richardson observed, the monthly numbers until March were already showing a small surplus.

The government has data, which the rest of us don't, for April that has clearly made it confident the surplus would be significant.After the political caning that Labor has received for years about its economic management, this should be manna from heaven.Except it's a pretty bad political look to have a huge surplus and not to have made some structural spending decisions in core Labor areas to address years of Coalition parsimony.The government has rolled out budget announcements for weeks, at a pace not unlike election years of old.We still have to go through the veil dance, though, of it being okay to tell us "so much" but then not have questions answered because we "have to wait for budget night".In the circumstances, the government can hardly complain about howls of indignation about partial announcements of decisions that people can't assess because they aren't quite announced, and also because of the context in which they have been made.One example of this is the speculation - not denied - that the government will boost the JobSeeker rate for people aged over 55, but not for all those younger than 55 who face the same sort of financial distress.The government argues other groups will get different cost-of-living assistance.Well, we do have to wait until budget night to assess just what they have done.Sources say there was a flurry of activity in the past few days to try to find places to stash about $20 billion of spending to get the surplus back to a less-embarrassing size.The difficulty, in a time of inflationary pressures, is that while a short-term boost in the budget would suggest the capacity for one-off payments to help people with the cost of living which aren't baked in long term, there is perhaps nothing quite so inflationary as that sort of spending.Such a complicated story to tell.And, to date, no really clear narrative.Laura Tingle is the chief political correspondent at the ABC's 7.30.

documents.result_message: Our detector is moderately confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: The nation Dropping $240m on a stadium in Hobart is at odds with what the Labor government has forecast about the future.It's not often a prime minister gets heckled for making a major funding announcement, particularly when it's a major funding announcement involving football.But in what feels like a symbol of a contradictory set of messages from the federal government in the lead-up to Tuesday's Budget, Anthony Albanese was filmed striding across derelict land in Hobart last Saturday, pursued by protesters heckling him as he announced $240 million of funding for a new football stadium.The protesters weren't just political fringe dwellers expressing a minority opinion. The proposal to build a football stadium at Macquarie Point has been widely unpopular for some time. Apart from a poll showing 67 per cent of Tasmanians were against the stadium, it has been opposed by state Labor, the Greens, federal independents and federal Liberals.As Richard Flanagan wrote in The Age this week, Tasmanians living in the poorest state with the lowest incomes have endured the nation's biggest rental increases in the past five years, have the highest increase in homelessness, the worst public heath system and, with 50 per cent rate of functional illiteracy, a public education problem.Yet the state government has committed $375 million to the stadium project which is now viable thanks to the federal commitment. And the AFL? Well, it is chucking in just $15 million on the promise that it will not have to pay any more if costs blow out.So why on earth would Albanese get involved? The fig leaf that seeks to make a virtue of the federal government's involvement is the sudden materialisation of references to broader urban renewal, and notably social and affordable housing on the site about two months ago, when the prime minister was being asked about the project."We're considering proposals as part of our budget measures, but I make this point, we're considering it as part of an urban redevelopment and urban policy," he said on February 23. "That is a prime site for not just a sporting stadium, if that goes ahead, but for residential, for recreational, for commercial activity as well."A submission was "being made". A submission (still forthcoming) that would clearly differ from a plan that made no reference to urban renewal or housing.Even now, if you care to look it up, artist impressions show a dirty, big stadium and a vaguely shaded-in area nearby which "could" be the possible site of some housing.How much housing? The original number mentioned was just 120 homes - though the suggestion this week is that there might be more after the government tweaked its housing fund plan to guarantee a minimum of 1200 homes would be built in Tasmania over the next five years.Given this has all been magicked up in record time, it will be interesting to hear at Senate estimates just how much detailed infrastructure planning was put forward to the federal government before it "apparently" committed to this funding last week.Infrastructure Minister Catherine King told ABCHobart on Tuesday that "the first thing is the Tasmanian government needs to come back to the Commonwealth with a precinct plan that includes the housing development, social and affordable housing" among other things, "as they develop that plan with the RSL, with Hobart City Council and with First Nations communities as they go through that".This would just be a story about what looks like tin-eared politics and decisions on the run with few ramifications in the rest of the country, if it wasn't for the fact there seems to be a bit of that vibe going on more broadly in the past few weeks.For starters, there's the eye watering amounts of money being spent on defence - even before the revelations that there was a $123 billion contingency for cost overruns on the nuclear submarine program, let alone the subsequent big investment decisions which keep coming for other forms of kit.Yet on the other side of the fence, the government keeps warning us about how tough things are in the budget: how it had to find another $5 billion for "unfunded" government programs and activities (that is, programs that the previous government only funded until this year); and detailed releases about huge debt interest bills linked to the former government.And there is the one constant message that although this coming year might look okay, the years beyond will look worse, which constrains the government from doing all that people ask of it to improve the condition of the more than 3 million people living below the poverty line.The optics of the PM attending the multimillion-dollar wedding of a shock jock in the company of underworld figures, before jetting off to mix with royalty at the coronation might have further confused voters who felt that they had a handle on their working-class prime minister.If all these messages weren't making things complicated enough, an obscene amount of revenue has emerged in recent days from underforecast profits that suggests the budget's heading for a significant surplus - the first in 15 years.As economist Chris Richardson observed, the monthly numbers until March were already showing a small surplus. The government has data, which the rest of us don't, for April that has clearly made it confident the surplus would be significant.After the political caning that Labor has received for years about its economic management, this should be manna from heaven.Except it's a pretty bad political look to have a huge surplus and not to have made some structural spending decisions in core Labor areas to address years of Coalition parsimony.The government has rolled out budget announcements for weeks, at a pace not unlike election years of old.We still have to go through the veil dance, though, of it being okay to tell us "so much" but then not have questions answered because we "have to wait for budget night".In the circumstances, the government can hardly complain about howls of indignation about partial announcements of decisions that people can't assess because they aren't quite announced, and also because of the context in which they have been made.One example of this is the speculation - not denied - that the government will boost the JobSeeker rate for people aged over 55, but not for all those younger than 55 who face the same sort of financial distress.The government argues other groups will get different cost-of-living assistance.Well, we do have to wait until budget night to assess just what they have done.Sources say there was a flurry of activity in the past few days to try to find places to stash about $20 billion of spending to get the surplus back to a less-embarrassing size.The difficulty, in a time of inflationary pressures, is that while a short-term boost in the budget would suggest the capacity for one-off payments to help people with the cost of living which aren't baked in long term, there is perhaps nothing quite so inflationary as that sort of spending.Such a complicated story to tell.And, to date, no really clear narrative.Laura Tingle is the chief political correspondent at the ABC's 7.30.
